messageBody:
On 11/30/06, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> On 11/30/06, Neil Swingler <neil@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> > assert(that(n).greaterThan(2).and().that(n).lessThan(10))
>
>
> Sure, this works. But honestly, compare:
>
> assert(that(n).greaterThan(2).and().that(n).lessThan(10))
>
> and
>
> assert (n > 2 && n < 10)
>
> I know which one I prefer to see in my code (notwithstanding the fact that
> it's not clear to me that lessThan means "<" and not "<=").
>
> Natural languages are great for humans but not so great for programming, so
> let's exercise caution where we draw the line...

Others may disagree with me here, but the fact that the names of
constraint constructors are in natural language is also not a big
factor in favor of assertThat. In the same way, I'd love to use
aList[3] to retrieve the third element of a list, but the
object-oriented nature of lists is enough better than arrays to be
worth the pain of calling it aList.get(3).

Or perhaps we're not talking about assertThat anymore?

David Saff
